indications:
Indications type 2 diabetes mellitus not controlled
by metformin alone
name: VILDAGLIPTIN WITH METFORMIN
cautions:
Cautions determine renal function before treatment
and at least annually (at least twice a year in patients with additional
risk factors for renal impairment, or if deterioration suspected); monitor liver function (see below); interactions: Appendix 1 (antidiabetics)Liver toxicity Rare reports of liver dysfunction; monitor liver function before treatment and every 3 months for the
first year and periodically thereafter; advise patients to seek prompt medical attention if symptoms such
as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, fatigue, and dark urine develop; discontinue if jaundice or other signs of liver dysfunction
occurLactic acidosis Use with caution
in renal impairment—increased risk of lactic acidosis; avoid if eGFR less than 50 mL/minute/1.73 m2. Withdraw or interrupt treatment in those
at risk of tissue hypoxia or sudden deterioration in renal function,
such as those with dehydration, severe infection, shock, sepsis, acute
heart failure, respiratory failure or hepatic impairment, or those
who have recently had a myocardial infarction
side-effects:
Side-effects nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea (usually transient),
abdominal pain, taste disturbance, peripheral oedema, headache, tremor,
anorexia, asthenia, dizziness; less commonly constipation,
hypoglycaemia, arthralgia; rarely hepatic dysfunction
(see also Liver Toxicity above), lactic acidosis (withdraw treatment),
decreased vitamin-B12 absorption, erythema, pruritus, and
urticaria; very rarely nasopharyngitis, upper respiratory
tract infection; pancreatitis also reported
doses:
adult over 18 years, 1
tablet twice daily (based on patient’s current metformin dose)

adult over 18 years, 1
tablet twice daily (based on patient’s current metformin dose)

patients to seek prompt medical attention if symptoms such as nausea,
